column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/crunch-time-for-the-mike-evans-streak/|Crunch Time For The Mike Evans Streak|To the best of Joe’s knowledge
column2: Mike Evans didn’t look happy walking off the field last Sunday in Tampa and didn’t talk to reporters after the game.  Also
column3: to the best of Joe’s knowledge
column4: Evans didn’t chat with media this past week. Odd. But Joe is not making assumptions. There could be all kinds of reasons. However
column5: Joe wonders how Evans feels about getting only five targets Sunday against the Raiders while the Bucs offense struggled for long stretches. Evans’ streak of 10 consecutive seasons with 1
column6: 000 yards or more receiving hangs in the balance. The future Hall of Fame receiver has 43 catches this season for 590 yards and 7 touchdowns. And there are only four games remaing on the schedule. Extending Evans’ streak of 1
column7: 000-yard seasons to 11 years would tie the NFL record held by Jerry Rice. It’s important to Evans. It’s important to Baker Mayfield. It’s important to fans. And it’s important to the power hitters at One Buc Palace. So what are the Bucs going to do about it? A low output game for Evans against the Chargers’ stout pass defense tomorrow would supremely hurt his chances of extending the streak. Whatever happens against the Chargers
column8: Evans’ targets total needs to hit 10. Joe believes. Evans’ 5 targets against the Raiders was a thoroughly unacceptable total for any game in which Evans plays four quarters. Put the ball in the hands of your best players. It’s hard to go wrong doing that. With Baker Mayfield at quarterback
column9: the Bucs have a 6-4 record (including playoffs) when Evans gets 10 or more targets. Joe really doesn’t want to be writing an obituary on the Evans streak later this month. That would be a sad
column10: sad day. Ira Kaufman Talks Jason Licht Comments

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/will-deep-shot-fears-doom-tampa-bay/|Will Deep-Shot Fears Doom Tampa Bay?|A standout defensive coordinator in NFL history once issued advice to a Buccaneers’ playcaller and head coach
column2: and it stuck. The advice was simple: “Throw deep.” The order was given to Dirk Koetter decades ago by Marvin Lewis
column3: the architect of the Ravens’ iconic defense from 1996-2001 and the former Bengals head coach. Lewis kept it simple. Throwing deep terrorizes defense and offenses don’t do it enough. Enter Todd Bowles. Those who scrutinize the Bucs pass defense know it’s a unit obsessed with not getting beat deep. Bowles’ defensive backs generally do a great job with that — while decent quarterbacks carve them up short to a too-often painful degree. Now enter Bucs offensive coordinator Liam Coen. He’s largely pulled the plug on the Bucs taking deep shots this season. Hey
column5: but for how long? Joe thinks it’s ironic that Bowles is so dialed into his defense not being beaten by long throws as his playcaller feels no urge to throw deep. Tomorrow against the Chargers (8-5)
column6: the Bucs (7-6) will face a team severely lacking deep-threat weapons. QB Justin Herbert has just five completions of 40 or more yards this season after only four last year. Does that mean Bowles will tighten his soft zone and not worry about the long ball? Will Coen test the Chargers’ elite pass defense that surely won’t be looking for Mike Evans or Trey Palmer to run a go route? Joe has a sneaky feeling that a deep ball will be the key play in tomorrow’s game. Ira Kaufman Talks Jason Licht Comments

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/time-sucking-todd-bowles/|Time-Sucking Todd Bowles|So a couple of ex-Bucs coaches are chiming in on Sunday’s Bucs-Chargers game.  Joe’s referring to former Bucs center and 2021 Bucs assistant offensive line coach A.Q. Shipley and Jay Gruden
column2: a Bucs assistant before his head coaching gig with the Redskins (2014-2019). They host a YouTube show on the Clean Pocket channel with longtime Giants offensive lineman Justin Pugh and retired QB Colt McCoy. The discussion turned to preparing to face defenses late in a season and Gruden explained that Todd Bowles teams are nightmares at that time of year. He said an offensive staff might need five hours just to study all the Bowles blitzes
column3: nickel blitzes and odd fronts. Gruden called it “very time consuming” and noted that while Bowles demands an offense be creative
column4: it can distract an offense from focusing on what they do best. Now Joe thought Gruden might be exaggerating (he’s prone to that)
column5: but Shipley chimed in and agreed. He noted how in his one year of coaching the Bucs
column6: he realized the chess match for offensive coaches can be overhwhelming late in a season against teams with diverse defenses. And few teams have as many defensive nuances as the Bucs’ do. Hmmmm
column7: could this be a reason Bowles teams seem to thrive late in a year? Gruden is convinced the Bucs want a “physical
column8: bloodbath matchup” on offense to limit the dropback passes for Baker Mayfield with beastly edge rushers Khalil Mack and Joey Bosa lurking. Gruden picked the Bucs to beat the Chargers
column9: if Mayfield can protect the football and the Bucs can spit out just enough run defense. Pugh thinks the Bucs will win
column10: in part because they don’t have to overthink their offense. Running the ball
column11: using Mike Evans and smart scrambling by Mayfield should be enough to topple a weak Chargers offense
column12: he said. It wasn’t all flowers for the Bucs. Colt McCoy picked the Chargers because he’s studied the Bucs pass defense. “I think you’ll see more from Herbert and the skill guys
column14: a huge Bucs fan and supporter

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/jason-licht-on-bucky-irving-hes-going-to-be-a-true-pro-for-the-rest-of-his-career/|Jason Licht On Bucky Irving: “He’s Going To Be A True Pro For The Rest Of His Career”|Will Bucky Irving suit up tomorrow? Bucs coach Todd Bowles said the team won’t know until the rookie warms up prior to the game against the Chargers in Los Angeles. So Joe understands why Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht seemed rather coy with popular national sports TV and radio personality Adam Schein when Licht appeared Wednesday on “Schein on Sports
column2: ” heard on “Mad Dog Radio” exclusively on SiriusXM. There
column3: Schein asked Licht if Irving could play and admitted he’s concerned about Irving being a little guy and with potential endurance issues. “We’re doing everything we can to get him ready
column4: ” Licht said. “He didn’t really have a setback [against the Raiders]. “Just his back tightened up and [Bucs trainers and coaches] saw he wasn’t himself down on the field. They just wanted to shelter him a little bit. Get him off the field.” Irving had a catch and run for 15 yards and carried the ball four times for three yards before the Bucs shut him down. Still
column5: the Bucs ran for 152 yards. “We’re fortunate we’ve got Rachaad White and Sean Tucker on our roster as well who are outstanding players
column7: ” Licht said. “We need all three of them to make this run.” Licht made no secret of his belief that Irving was just the shot in the arm the Bucs’ run game needed when he was drafted. “Bucky has been a breath of fresh air for this organization
column9: his professionalism. He meets with [Bucs senior offensive assistant] Tom Moore every day at 5 a.m. for like 10 minutes. “He just can’t wait to get to work every day.” Despite having a troubled upbringing
column10: Licht said (Irving’s father died when he was a toddler and a brother was shot and killed when he was in high school)
column11: Irving exudes a contagious positive attitude in the running backs room. “He didn’t grow up in a great house like most of us did
column12: ” Licht said. “And he still has a great outlook on life. “He’s going to be a true pro for the rest of his career. I’m excited about his future.” The numbers say it all. When Irving got more carries early in the season
column13: the Bucs offense and the run game started to take off. Ira Kaufman Talks Jason Licht Comments

column2: Rookies And A Depleted Safety Position|Is Tykee Smith still a rookie? Well
column6: no. Coaches often consider rookies to be veterans late in a season. The reasoning is
column7: the rookie has seen enough that little should surprise him
column8: if he’s been playing a lot. Joe asked Bowles about that this week and Bowles believes if a player shows enough savvy and smarts
column9: he’s no longer a rookie in the summer. “We try to make that saying in August
column10: ” Bowles said on Wednesday when Joe asked him about Jalen McMillan seemingly turning the corner. “Once you have your first meetings and first day of practice
column11: you’re no longer a rookie.” But with nickel corner Tykee Smith
column12: Bowles seems to be treating the rookie like
column14: a rookie. With so many safeties hurt and not expected to play Sunday
column15: Bowles was asked if he may flip Smith
column17: between safety and corner in Los Angeles against the Chargers. Bowles did a little bit of that against the Raiders. Bowles didn’t seem to favor that as he said that may be too much for the rookie. “It’s probably too much to put on his plate right now
column19: ” Bowles said. “.We try to give him what he can handle but I think he’s a good football player and
column21: he can go back there.” So much for becoming a seasoned veteran in August. Joe isn’t terribly worried about the injuries at safety. Not this week.
